Journal.Title: Clinical infectious diseases : an official publication of the Infectious Diseases Society of America

Article.ArticleTitle: Positive Effects of Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy Targeting Severe Fatigue Following COVID-19 Are Sustained Up to 1 Year After Treatment.

MedlineCitation.CoiStatement: Potential conflicts of interest. F. M. declares funding from the NKCV Foundation. C. P. R. declares grants as a payment to their institution for the present study, EU Horizon 2020 Research and Innovation Framework Programme: Pandemic Preparedness and Response (PANDEM-2); being an unpaid member of the committee “Pandemic Preparedness Plan” of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences; and an unpaid member of the committee “Long-term effects of COVID-19” of the Health Council of the Netherlands. H. K. declares funding for this study by the Netherlands Organization for Health Research and Development (ZonMw: project number 10430012010025, research program COVID-19), with payments made to their institution. H. K. also declares grants from ZonMw to conduct research into long COVID-19 and post-Lyme symptoms, from the Dutch Cancer Society, MS Research, Pfizer, and the NKCV Foundation. All other authors report no potential conflicts. All authors have submitted the ICMJE Form for Disclosure of Potential Conflicts of Interest. Conflicts that the editors consider relevant to the content of the manuscript have been disclosed.
